Hello, ethOS node. üî•
h/t @joenrv https://t.co/0LFjszEUul
gm https://t.co/GapVIxPo8A
https://t.co/WiOpUmMdoo

P.S. If you'd like to test ethOS on a Pixel 3, instructions are at the link below. As always, if you have any questions or need help, find us in the Discord! üíú

https://t.co/F61UC6xMG0

And that‚Äôs a wrap of the second ethOS community call! 

If you‚Äôre interested contributing to, or simply following the project, please join our discord and introduce yourself!

Audio of of the call below, -see you next call!üöÄ
https://t.co/gYqozVasU8

A: Opensea is a an easy one. There is no native buy experience in their app, because of existing store policies.

ethOS solves this.
Last Q from community: 'Example of an app that google or Apple censored that people might be able to use here?'

Rahul adds that ethOS will have big unlocks for devs integrating on a system level, but there's design delights unlocked for users on a native web3 OS. Ex: NFT wallpapers, status of txs in phone status bar, GWEI widget on home screen, etc. Little things add up to ‚ÜóÔ∏è experience.

Noginton then explains that if you'd like to contribute to ethOS from a design perspective, the best way is to get creative and prototype features that you yourself would like to use, and then share it in the discord where we can talk through it together.

Next, Nogington walks though Rahul‚Äôs design of a startup sequence.

We are early imagining how Ethereum can integrate into a phone OS. Demos startup sequence having a native wallet connection, and minting of an NFT with an ethOS native system level wallet.
A: Good thought, -Joaquin shares that he is often in touch with them, and can certainly talk about what we can learn, and look for opportunities to work together.

Another Q from the community:

Dappnode creates linux based OS for node operators preinstalled w/VPN & UI. Can we look at what they‚Äôve done & have decentralized app store for node operators that can one-click run a node on their machine? Can we learn or work with them?

A: Nothing stopping them from providing a great device with ethOS. Users choose devices on many factors. We encourage them building right device for their audience.¬† OEMs using ethOS would be a win, and we‚Äôll always be an open alternative, developing under our guiding principles.

Another question:

'If it‚Äôs open source, what‚Äôs stopping companies from coming in and providing a great phone with this OS and then centrazling it. Have you thought about that?‚Äô

The app store itself will look similar to other app stores, but devs building web3 apps in existing stores can just get rejected, or pay 30% rev share. These pain points aren‚Äôt actually about decentralizatoin. They‚Äôre about user & dev problems that are literally impossible today.

A: This is why we started ethOS. One pain points now is the wallet experience on mobile. No browser extensions, & if we had, doesn‚Äôt address problem of native apps. We can do so much better w/the wallet bridging on ethOS at the system level. This experience should be seamless.

Question from the community:

'Seems best projects are 10x what is offered by alternatives. ethOS could be in a strong position if product is better and decentralization isn‚Äôt the only differentiator. How can product be better?'

Next Nogington talks design. A lot of the work we‚Äôre doing now is exploratory on how to serve the possibilities of Ethereum integrated at a mobile OS and hardware level. Design is currently helping build the tools for the UIs for some of these items.

Tweet limit reached which broke the thread, so continuing on...

Our Statement of Principles is living, public, and we welcome community feedback, which we would love to hear in the Discord. https://t.co/P1thk2kSz1 https://t.co/glMMjOGe14

3) ethOS is free, opensource, and decentralized.

Others should be able to develop with ethOS & extend it, & it should be community driven & decentralized. This is why calls like this and your feedback are so important. User perspective is invaluable to guide the project.

While the MVP is hard, it targets the earliest adopters. Eventually it will be preloaded onto devices with the complexity of web3 abstracted away. A lot of our work on light nodes, wallet bridging, and system services will come into play here.

2) ethOS is simple and intuitive to use.

We can‚Äôt succeed if it's harder to use than alternatives. Harder = less traction and doesn't serve the goal of creating a decentralized OS.

1) Users have Privacy, Transparency, and Control.

We believe in being transparent on what the OS is doing, enhancing the privacy of users, and giving them the most control to handle how they use their data in the web3 ecosystem.

Next up, Rish talks about the Principles that guide the development of the ethOS project.

How are we thinking not just about the next 6 months, but years long development cycles? We are guided by three main principles:

There is a lot of cool stuff not on short term roadmap. Mark shares that after connecting w/team and seeing the challenges overcome and possibilities unfold, his excitement has only grown at the prospect of having an OS layer available for web3 development.

3) Community: Attract more people interested not just in building, but in helping us test, break, and fix what we release, then build more support around this community to turn it into an efficient system of releases, testing, feedback, and updates around the builds.

2) Decentralized ethOS app store: ethOS users can find, download, and install APKs from the store, and devs can upload these APKs to IPFS by listing them with our smart contract, and manage them. Also, build a knowledge base for devs to help them do this easily.

Roadmap a living doc modified by community feedback.

First¬† 6 month has 3¬†goals:

1) ethOS MVP done: (we're close). Includes the Lineage fork of Android with a native wallet, light client, and wallet bridge, that is flash installed by the user on Pixel 3. Other devices after.

Next, Mark tells us about the 6 month roadmap. Reiterates that ethOS welcomes engineers as well as designers, writers, and coordinators.

This distributed team selects for initiative, persistence, and passion.

A LOT of work has been done so far in the past two months.

Next an audience Q: How do devs get involved? A: Discord is where everything happens. Be visible, ask to help w/piece you feel you can contribute. Very organic. Takes self motivation/initiative. We appreciate people asking Qs,¬†& owning a piece. We can give tasks to do.

If you are testing ethOS and have stability issues, feature requests, or feedback, let us know in the discord #testing channel.

Besides testers, ethOS needs engineers w/experience in android AOSP in particular, as well as web and blockchain infra. There is a lot to do, -join us!

WE NEED TESTERS! Pixel 3 is easiest: You can install test version now. You can build for your own device, but not guaranteed to work. If you try &have issues, contact us Markus in Discord and he‚Äôll help. This will also help us expand support for more devices eventually.
A native Light node lets users connect to the blockchain trustlessly without relying on Infura or Alchemy, and also lets developers not have to pay API fees to Infura or Alchemy.
With light node constantly running, we get 10 hours battery life, which is passable for MVP, but we are continuing optimizations to make node experience like it isn‚Äôt even there for users.

We‚Äôve been working hard to integrate a light node into ethOS, & have a first working version. ATM if you install ethOS on your device, you have a running light node at all times. We chose the Google Pixel 3 as our benchmark test device we‚Äôre currently building against.

The grand vision is to create a standard where Android wallets can interact with dApps. We‚Äôre working on this currently, and we‚Äôll be sharing our progress as we go.

Next Markus talks about ethOS‚Äôs native Ethereum light node capability, & the need for testers in the community.

Second, give mobile-first devs an API that lets them create apps that better interact with other dApps or wallets on Android.

The first version supports Wallet Connect compatible wallets.

Next, Nicola discusses wallet bridging, and the two goals ethOS has for its implementation:

First, make the UX when interacting with the wallet and dApps improved compared to mobile wallets + web apps.

The Dev Portal is a web3 app where devs can connect their wallet, load their apps, deploy to chain, and manage all deployed apps. Good progress has been made with major paths covered, & now working on tweaks like increasing the size of APKs you can upload. No major snags so far.

Next, Stipe talks about the Dev Portal. He explains how the chain is the source of truth for the apps, and that the goal is to keep the data deployed to the chain lightweight, meaning APKs are stored somewhere else.

That place is IPFS.

This flow works now, fetching data from the chain, letting you browse apps and download them on to your phone.

Jaoquim concludes that progress is coming along well with this team that formed organically, together, around a common ideal.

Jaoquim is working in conjunction with Stipe on the developer web app side, where devs can upload their APKs to our smart contract through our Dev Portal, and¬† ethOS will fetch the data from the smart contract to display the App Store experience that you‚Äôd expect.

First up is recapping where ethOS development currently is, starting with the decentralized ethOS App Store.
Jaoquim explains that the store has no fees to list apps, no restrictions to list as with Apple/Google stores, no 30% cut of transactions taken. A big win for web3 devs.

Did you miss the 2nd ethOS community call, and are looking for a full summary? Let‚Äôs jump in!
